messageBody:
How many differences (D, E & F, below) are there?

Greek, Russian and English all use certain identical characters such as "A," "Y," & "M," yet they use different fonts (a source of a special Internet security problem).

German and English use "W" quite differently even tho German is commonly written in a purely English font, and special German letters are included in many "Roman" fonts I have seen. No one cares that German & English words are on the same page: "I had a wonderful wine while staying in old Wien."

I would say that vast differences make for different fonts - otherwise not.

And, if not vastly different, then "reuse" shapes as is normally done despite the differences in sound. Context or special marks can differentiate, and characters described by A & B below can be treated the same as non-Latin characters (such as from Portuguese, Swedish or German) that are included in "Roman" fonts.


> My take on it is to only re-use Shavian characters where there would be
> no confusion.

I think all agree on this. We now need to reach detailed agreement
on which Shavian characters can be reused and which cannot. I
propose the following taxonomy:

A. Some Shavian characters, like the r-colored vowels, have no
Quickscript equivalents.

B. Some Quickscript characters, like Loch and Llan, have no Shavian
equivalents.

C. Some Quickscript characters have exact Shavian equivalents,
agreeing in both sound and shape.

D. Some Quickscript characters have exact Shavian equivalents in
sound, but are not like any Shavian character in shape.

E. Some Quickscript characters have exact Shavian equivalents in
shape, but are not like any Shavian character in sound.

F. Some Quickscript characters have an exact Shavian equivalent in
sound, and a different exact Shavian equivalent in shape.

Now which are which?
